alignement module¶

Algorithm of brutal force alignment.

In order to find an optimal alignment between two sequences we define a score system: we determine a score when two caracters are identical, another when they are not and another when a caracter is aligned with a gap. The final score of the aligment is the sum of all the scores. The optimal alignment is the one that has the higher score of all the possible alignments.

alignement.ali_optimaux(liste_att)[source]¶

Function to find the optimal alignment between two sequences.

Parameters:liste_att (list) – List containing all the possible alignments of two sequences with their score.
Returns:A list containing only the alignments with the higher score.
Return type:liste_opti

Example: >>> ali_optimaux(enumerate_all_possibles_alignements(“AAC”,”AG”,1,-1,-1)) [[‘AAC’, ‘AG-‘, -1], [‘AAC’, ‘A-G’, -1], [‘AAC’, ‘-AG’, -1]]

alignement.enumerate_all_possibles_alignements(seq1, seq2, reward_match, cost_mismatch, cost_gap)[source]¶

Function to find all the possible alignements between two sequences.

Parameters:
  • seq1 (str) – The first sequence to compare.
  • seq2 (str) – The second sequence to compare.
  • reward_match (int) – Value given when there is a match between the two sequences.
  • cost_mismatch (int) – Value given when there is a mismatch between the two sequences.
  • cost_gap (int) – Value given when there is a gap in one of the sequences.
Returns:

A list containing all the possible alignments of the two sequences and their score.
Return type:

final_list

Example: >>> enumerate_all_possibles_alignements(“AAC”,”AG”,1,-1,-1) [[‘–AAC’, ‘AG—’, -5], [‘-A-AC’, ‘A-G–’, -5], [‘-AA-C’, ‘A–G-‘, -5], [‘-AAC-‘, ‘A—G’, -5], [‘-AAC’, ‘A–G’, -4], [‘-AAC’, ‘A-G-‘, -4], [‘-AAC’, ‘AG–’, -4], [‘A–AC’, ‘-AG–’, -5], [‘A-A-C’, ‘-A-G-‘, -5], [‘A-AC-‘, ‘-A–G’, -5], [‘A-AC’, ‘-A-G’, -4], [‘A-AC’, ‘-AG-‘, -4], [‘AA–C’, ‘–AG-‘, -5], [‘AA-C-‘, ‘–A-G’, -5], [‘AA-C’, ‘–AG’, -4], [‘AAC–’, ‘—AG’, -5], [‘AAC-‘, ‘–AG’, -4], [‘AA-C’, ‘-AG-‘, -2], [‘AAC-‘, ‘-A-G’, -2], [‘AAC’, ‘-AG’, -1], [‘A-AC’, ‘AG–’, -2], [‘AA-C’, ‘A-G-‘, -2], [‘AAC-‘, ‘A–G’, -2], [‘AAC’, ‘A-G’, -1], [‘AAC’, ‘AG-‘, -1]]
